awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Skin-Voltage Biometric Sensing Using Highly Conductive Fabric Electrodes on Wearable Garments
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to broaden access to healthcare data. Users of the system developed in this project can take biometric measurements such as heart rate, muscle-activity, and body mass calculations in real-time, with data collected through sensors embedded into clothing.  The innovation enables vital measurements to be taken, both inside and outside of clinical environments, while reducing instrumentation weight and cost requirements. This fabric-based technology can potentially serve users ranging from medical professionals to everyday consumers who will more easily adopt wearable soft-material products in lieu of traditional hardware devices. Specialized sectors such as physical therapy, pre-surgical studies, sports labs, and out-patient care have the highest growth opportunity for new technology adoption. Complementing the rapid growth of telehealth, bio-sensing capabilities for real-time and remote tracking will improve patient compliance and aid health care workers by providing better access to comprehensive vital measurement data.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project involves material science research in conductive threads and fabrics. These soft goods can bend, stretch, and compress along the body where they are worn. In addition, their electromechanical characteristics allow them to pick up small voltage and current signals that are naturally generated from the body, specifically from the heart, muscles, and the brain. By strategically weaving these materials within a shirt, small voltages for EKG (heart), EMG (muscle), EEG (brain), and BIA (water and body mass content) can be simultaneously captured and measured for heart rate, muscle activity, brain activity, and water and fat content measurements. The technical research will involve innovation in fabric-materials optimized for small signal and low noise pickup and design of a comfortable garment incorporating multiple fabric-based electrodes for simultaneous pickup of EKG/EMG/BIA signals. The project will also develop new signal processing algorithms to transform raw voltages to real-time signals transmitted wirelessly. The desired technical result is a functional and wearable prototype with end-to-end communication from the fabric through the garment to a receiving mobile or desktop app visualizing the processed data for heart rate, muscle activity, and body mass analysis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of Nextiles' NSF SBIR Phase I grant was to develop conductive fabrics and yarns as more flexible and affordable substitutes for dry and wet electrodes for biometric sensing used in clinical and commercial settings. The purpose of the project's research into fabric-based conductive materials was to improve the form-factor, accessibility, and comfort-level of current electrophysiology equipment used for EKG (electrocardiography), EMG (electromyography), and EOG (electrooculography).

Nextiles was able to develop several conductive fabrics and yarns, with more than ten different fabrics assessed. Each material was assessed both mechanically and electrically. Mechanically, each material was made to be cut, died, sewn into, and embroidered for mostly all cut-and-sew machines and operations. Manufacturing and prototyping experiments were tested at the Nextiles' facility. In addition, each material was electrically analyzed for their internal resistance, sheet resistance, and changes in resistance due to mechanical deformation or perturbation such as applied pressure, twisting, and bending.

During the project, Nextiles developed accessory technologies that allowed the conductive fabric to be embedded with standard electronic devices such as electromechanical connectors and Bluetooth devices. The purpose was to construct a final prototype that could be delivered at the conclusion of the project. The final prototype(s) being a shirt for EKG, compressive sleeve for EMG, and a facemask for EOG. These additional hardware components were also made to be sewable into the prototypes using Nextiles patent (pending) flexible and sewable connector technology. The research and development involved in the final prototype included pattern making, techpack assembly which includes a bill of material (BOM) and point of measurement (POM), as well as customizing the sewn routes between the connectors and controller to the fabric electrodes.

With the deliverable, the prototypes were used to collect preliminary data to compare against gold standard electrophysiological waveforms. The results in this project show a strong feasibility for commercial use, as well as for potential application in clinical studies. Signal-to-noise ratios (SNR) and waveforms such as heart rate (EKG), heart pulse pattern (EKG QRS complex), muscle activity (EMG), and eye movement (EOG) were within 10%-15% of off-the-shelf devices. In addition, data acquisition bandwidth was observed to go as high as >100 Hz, allowing granular signal analysis for peak phase and frequency response. Ongoing work will focus on further enhancing the data acquisition circuitry, as well as developing algorithms to further filter and implement machine learning insights for consumer use once the prototypes evolve into a commercializable form.

Work that can be conducted in a Phase II is to develop algorithms in which to transform raw data into easily interpretable metrics for consumer, sport, and medical personnel. Examples of metrics could be heart rate (EKG), time of intense or low muscle activity (EMG), and types of eye activity (EOG). With these promising results, we plan to further expand to other fabric-based electrophysiology capabilities such as BIA (bioelectric impedance analysis), EDA (electrodermal activity), and SIA (skin impedance analysis). The goal is to combine these modalities into a unified system, such as a shirt or leggings, to reduce the equipment burden and cost when performing any electrophysiological measurements and experiments.
